title: Palmer launches new legal attack on CITIC
text:
Mon, Aug 31, 2015, 8:11 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets closed Palmer launches new legal attack on CITIC AAP – 44 minutes ago Print 
Clive Palmer's Mineralogy has launched a fresh legal action against Chinese-owned enterprise CITIC Limited over claims it owes the Australian company $10 billion in damages. 
The Palmer United Party founder announced on Monday proceedings had been filed in the Supreme Court of Western Australia. 
He said the huge figure was derived from the "net present value" of royalties which CITIC was obliged to pay to his private company. 
"This is purely in respect to money that they owe us from minerals they have taken from Australia back to China, and not paid even one cent for," Mr Palmer said at Mineralogy's Brisbane office. 
The foreign company had shipped up to $500 million worth of iron ore concentrate without meeting its contractual obligations, he claimed. 
Mr Palmer said this meant the legal action - the latest in a string between the two former venture partners - would likely be upheld. 
The dispute also relates to the payment of royalties by CITIC, separated into A and B components. 
Mr Palmer has previously won a court ruling to compel CITIC to pay the so-called A component. 
But he says CITIC in turn refused to pay royalty B, stressing that separate court proceedings to determine the value of that component wouldn't affect the new claim. 
This was "unconscionable behaviour" and repudiated the companies' agreement, current Mineralogy chairman Clive Mensink said in a statement. 
It comes after the mining magnate turned politician won a court battle with subsidiaries of CITIC Pacific earlier this year. 
The Supreme Court in Brisbane dismissed claims Mineralogy misappropriated more than $12 million from a fund established to manage a port connected to the Sino Iron project in Western Australia. 
But just weeks ago, he was less pleased with the decision of the Federal Court in a separate legal stoush with CITIC. 
The court dismissed Mineralogy's attempt to block the state-owned enterprise from exporting iron ore from the Cape Preston Port.
